Award.AbstractNarration:
Bolivia represents one of the world's richest countries for mosses. Mosses are among the smallest of plants; however they play a major role in the Andean ecosystem, particularly in the mountain forest and humid puna (alpine) regions. These plants quickly absorb water from rainfall or fog mist, and then gradually release the water into the immediate environment, thus they moderate water flow, arrest erosion, and assist in preventing landslides and flooding down slope. Continuing degradation of the existing natural landscape in Bolivia (e.g., deforestation), coupled with rapid deglaciation, will have a major impact on the ecosystem, particularly the availability of water. This project will provide documentation of the more than 900 mosses in the country through field inventories of the highly diverse ecological regions of Bolivia. This 'Final Phase' project will complete the researchers' goal to document the diversity of mosses in Bolivia.

Descriptive text and database collections will be made accessible by a project web page to the scientific community and general public. Two major publications will be produced; first, an illustrated guide to the 69 families and 275 genera, intended for beginning students or those unfamiliar with mosses; second, a technical illustrated treatment for species identification intended for biologists and conservationists. To promote public awareness of these organisms, educational material will be prepared specifically for high school and university students, park staff, and those interested in natural history. Furthermore, environmental changes make it critical and timely that the ecological role of these organisms be documented. The collection data and descriptive treatments of the mosses will provide the means to study further the diversity and ecological role of these organisms. Through workshops and direct collaboration the project will foster a community of Bolivians with the experience and expertise to ensure continuation of bryological knowledge and research for future generations in the country.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project entitled Mosses of Bolivia, Final Phase, focused on completing a survey and inventory of the mosses throughout Bolivia in all nine major natural vegetation regions (ecoregions), and ascertaining overall moss diversity for the country. Summarizing this diversity is in the form of descriptions and data for families, genera and species. There are now recorded for Bolivia 963 species distributed among 281 genera and 69 families. Over the tenure of this project more than 20,000 collections were made resulting in 132 additional recorded mosses, and four potentially new species. At present, among the Latin American countries, Bolivia is the most diverse country with regard to mosses.

 

While the major goal focused on inventory and taxonomic treatment of the Bolivian mosses, the results of this effort also contributed to additional information. Specifically an increased knowledge of 1) ecoregion diversity and composition, 2) elevational diversity, and 3) enhanced geographical distributions. Prior to this project very little was known among the tropical Andean countries (Venezuela, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Bolivia) with regard to the diversity and composition of each of the major ecoregions (vegetation zones) with regard to mosses. Examination of the nine major Bolivian ecoregions demonstrated that montane forests covering just 5% of the land surface were the most diverse, with 70% of all known species. Altitudinal diversity for mosses was highest between 2000-2500 meters with 40% of all species found within this 500 meter range. This inventory also resulted in defining geographical range limits, including the extensions in the lowlands for the southwest Amazon basin, east-central semi-deciduous (Chiquitano) forest, and northern Chaco; in the highlands the southern limits of tropical Andean species from the puna, montane forest, and dry inter-Andean.

 

An indirect outcome of the project was a significant increase in the knowledge of hepatics that were included in the survey and inventory. More than 5000 hepatics were collected, resulting in information on the ecology and distribution of 505 species distributed among 111 genera and 38 families. Approximately 44 additional species records were made during the project.

 

Nine thesis students, conducting their research on bryophytes, were mentored during the project tenure. These students, the first Bolivians choosing bryophytes as a thesis topic, were from four universities in Cochabamba, La Paz, Santa Cruz and Sure. Eight of these graduated students continued to assist and work on the project for a limited or continues time period. Furthermore a major contribution was made by Bolivians with regard to field work; nearly 60% of the 26000 data based collections were made by Bolivian students and staff since the start of the project.

 

A total of 24 publications involving Bolivian mosses were generated during the project, the majority coauthored by Bolivians. This included checklists for Mididi National Park, Alarachi Natural Reserve, and Tucuman-Bolivian montane forests. A catalogue of the bryophytes of Bolivia (Catalogo de las Briofítas de Bolivia: La Diversidad, Distribución y Ecología) was published in book form. Outreach products included a booklet, Briofitas de Bolivia, intended for high school and university students, an illustrated neotropical moss glossary (Glosario Ilustrado para Musgos Neotropicales) for beginning students, and finally a bryophyte poster; these items were widely distributed and also available for download of the web page (see below).
